com.admob.android.ads
Class AdManager

java.lang.Object
  com.admob.android.ads.AdManager

public class AdManager
extends java.lang.Object

Provides data required to deliver ads. If you know more about the user, such as their gender or birthday, you can deliver more relevant advertisements to your users by setting those attributes here.

public static final java.lang.String SDK_VERSION_DATE
The release date of the SDK. It is in YYYYMMDD format.

Constant Field Values

SDK_VERSION

public static final java.lang.String SDK_VERSION
This SDK version. It is passed in every ad request in the client_sdk field. The server can use this for any version-specific logic.

Method Detail

getApplicationPackageName

public static java.lang.String getApplicationPackageName(android.content.Context context)
The application's unique package name such as "com.admob.android.ads". This is set in AndroidManifest.xml. Market links directly to this application will look like market://details?id=com.admob.android.ads.

Parameters:
context - is the application's context.
Returns:
The package name for this application.

getPublisherId

public static java.lang.String getPublisherId(android.content.Context context)
Gets the unique ID assigned to this application by AdMob.

Parameters:
context - is the application's context.
Returns:
The publisher ID for this application.

setPublisherId

public static void setPublisherId(java.lang.String id)
Programatic way to sets the unique publisher ID assigned to this application by AdMob. Typically, however, it is set in your AndroidManifest.xml by adding it within the "<application>" tag: 

        <meta-data android:name="ADMOB_PUBLISHER_ID" android:value="Your Publisher ID here" />

Parameters:
id - is the publisher ID for this application.

getTestAction

public static java.lang.String getTestAction()
Returns the type of test ad that will be returned. See setTestAction(String) for the possible test actions.

Returns:
The name of the test action or null for the default action.

setTestDevices

public static void setTestDevices(java.lang.String[] devices)
Causes test ads to be returned to the listed devices.

Look at LogCat to when requesting an ad to see how to return test ads to a device. There will be a log line with the code to add that looks like: 

   To get test ads on the emulator use AdManager.setTestDevices( new String[] { AdManager.TEST_EMULATOR } )
You can list several devices and quickly turn test ads on and off by commenting them out. For example: 
   AdManager.setTestAction( "app" );
   AdManager.setTestDevices( new String[] {
        AdManager.TEST_EMULATOR,
   //   "E83D20734F72FB3108F104ABC0FFC738",  // My T-Mobile G1 test phone
   } );

Test mode is enabled on a per-device basis. This ensures that if test mode is accidentally left on when publishing to the Market, users will not see test ads.

Parameters:
devices - is a list of all devices that test ads are returned for. Include the constant TEST_EMULATOR to get test ads in the emulator.

isTestDevice

public static boolean isTestDevice(android.content.Context context)
Returns true if this device will have test ads returned or false if real ads are returned.

Parameters:
context - is the application's context used to determine the current device's ID.
Returns:
true if the current device has been enabled for testing through setTestDevices(String[]).

setTestAction

public static void setTestAction(java.lang.String testAction)
Forces a specific type of test ad to be returned when in test mode. Optionally use this to see how your application responds when different types of ads are clicked.

The supported actions are:

  • url - (Default) Click-to-Browser for promoting websites
  • app - Click-to-Market for promoting Android applications
  • canvas - Click-to-Canvas which is a notice that appears over current screen
  • call - Click-to-Phone Call
  • map - Click-to-Google Map
  • video - Click-to-YouTube

Parameters:
testAction - sets the type of test ad returned or null to select the default.

getUserId

public static java.lang.String getUserId(android.content.Context context)
Returns a unique user ID.

Parameters:
context - is the activity's context used to get a unique ID for this user.
Returns:
The unique user ID. Will return null in the emulator.

setAllowUseOfLocation

public static void setAllowUseOfLocation(boolean useLocation)
Opts in or out of using location information for targeting ads. This method only has meaning for applications with either ACCESS_COARSE_LOCATION or ACCESS_FINE_LOCATION permission.

By default an application that has location permission does not use that information for targeting ads. Opting-in may increase the amount of money your application makes. Opting-out will remove the warning logged by the SDK reminding you to choose.

Normally this method is not used because this opt-in or opt-out choice can be set in AndroidManifest.xml. In the <application> tag add the following line (this one is set to true which opts in): 


        <meta-data android:value="true" android:name="ADMOB_ALLOW_LOCATION_FOR_ADS" />

Parameters:
useLocation - flag indicating whether or not to use location information for targeting ad requests.

getCoordinates

public static android.location.Location getCoordinates(android.content.Context context)
Returns the last known location of the user.

For this to return data the application needs permission to access the location services of the phone and you must opt-in to using it for ad targeting (see setAllowUseOfLocation(boolean)).

Parameters:
context - is the activity's context used to get the user's location.
Returns:
The last known location of the user or null if it is not known.

getPostalCode

public static java.lang.String getPostalCode()
Returns the birthday of the user. This is used to calculate their age.

Returns:
The birthday of the user or null if it is not known.

getOrientation

public static java.lang.String getOrientation(android.content.Context context)

setPostalCode

public static void setPostalCode(java.lang.String postalCode)
Set the postal code of the user if known to help geotargeting. If your application doesn't use course or fine location access, but it does have the user register their postal code, use this method to help target local ads to them.

Postal codes in the United States are zip codes like "94401". An example for the UK is "OX1 3DW".

Parameters:
postalCode - is the user's postal code within their country or null if it is not known.

getBirthday

public static java.util.GregorianCalendar getBirthday()
Returns the postal of the user as set in your code by previously calling setPostalCode.

Returns:
The birthday of the user or null if it is not known.

setBirthday

public static void setBirthday(java.util.GregorianCalendar birthday)
Sets the birthday of the user.

Parameters:
birthday - is the user's birthday or null if it is not known.

setBirthday

public static void setBirthday(int year,
                               int month,
                               int day)
Sets the birthday of the user.

Parameters:
year - is the year they were born in (e.g. 1976).
month - is the month they were born in (e.g. 3 for March).
day - is the day they were born on (e.g. 13 for the 13th).
